title: 106_s1468
content:
The Act is titled the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". It includes findings related to the Act. Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a symbol of democracy, receives millions of visitors annually, lacks necessary facilities, has excellent security provided by the Capitol Police, and is in the process of constructing a Visitor Center funded by both Congress and private donations. Congress also authorizes the minting of commemorative coins for this purpose. Authorization for coins commemorating the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building to aid in the construction, maintenance, and preservation of a Capitol Visitor Center. The text chunk "SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS." is a condensed summary of the section regarding the specifications of the coins authorized for commemorating the first convening of Congress in the Capitol building. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue various coins, including bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar coins, with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. If bimetallic coins are not feasible, $5 gold coins may be minted instead. The Secretary may mint and issue up to 100,000 $5 coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. Mintage levels specified in subsection (a) can be waived. The coins minted under this Act are legal tender. The Secretary obtains platinum and gold for minting coins from available sources, and may obtain silver from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins is specified under Section 5. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2000", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Capitol Preservation Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Coins will be issued as specified in Section 6. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each denomination and quality combination. These coins will be the first commemorative coins of the United States to bear the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission to establish a promotional role for the coins, and may enter into a contract for marketing purposes. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges for the coins will be set by the Secretary at specified amounts. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund for the construction, maintenance, and preservation of a Capitol Visitor Center.
